X.T: On n'est pas que des cobayes
The Most Complex International Borders in the World

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Enclaves, exclaves, counter-enclaves, unclaimed territory, Cyprus…

X.T: The Most Complex International Borders in the World - Part 2

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Armenia/Azerbaijan, Germany/Belgium, India/Pakistan/China…

X.T: Strangest Time Zones of the World

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some strange facts about some timezones.

X.T: What's the difference between Latino and Hispanic?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.
The title says all.
The history of Yugoslavia.

X.T: Notice explicative de la carte des curiosités géologiques de la Lorraine -- Rapport final -- BRGM/RP-57546-FR

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A long list of geological curiosities in Lorraine.

X.T: Comment les rivières, architectes puissants et minutieux, façonnent les paysages

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How some scientists are trying to understand the effects of rivers on the landscape.
A description of the chemical processes explaining how arsenic gets into drinking water.

X.T: How Water Can Identify Murder Victims and Fake Scotch
X.ST: These maps pinpoint an object’s origins by the isotope ratio in the water.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using the fact that the distribution of oxygen-18 and deuterium varies on earth to find the origin of a product or animal.

X.T: Evolution de cavités souterraines minières : une expérimentation unique dans le bassin salifère lorrain

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An experiment on a salt mine shows that microseismic sensors can be used to predict the cavity collapses.

X.T: Le sel à l'intérieur des terres

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of the salt (ecology, geology, industry) in Lorraine.
A good description of the extraction process in the years 1980's.
Second part of the previous video.
This video describes the preparation of ore and cock before putting them in the furnace.

X.T: Balade en Lorraine, le 12 : la mine de fer de Hussigny Godbrange

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Hussigny-Godbrange mine can be visited a few times per year. During these visits, animators demonstrate how people used to work there.

X.T: LA NAISSANCE DU FER A MANCIEULLES ( LORRAINE )

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some old pictures of the mine.
The burning mountain of Cransac, the underground mine of Carmaux and the open pit of Decazeville.

X.T: Poste du matin à la Houve

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A working day in the last French coal mine.
How to manage water after the coal mines are closed.

X.T: Paul Rothemund: The astonishing promise of DNA folding
Paul Rothemund: DNA folding, in detail

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Building molecular structures by folding DNA strands.

X.T: A Chinese Typewriter in Silicon Valley

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How the Chinese typists, during cultural revolution, customized their machines by using "predictive" layouts in order to type faster.

X.T: The Coming Technological Singularity: How to Survive in the Post-Human Era
The Coming Technological Singularity: How to Survive in the Post-Human Era

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Singularity: when human inventions will outperform humanity intelligence… Let's hope the Computer will core dump at that instant.

X.T: Why the future doesn't need us

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Bill Joy describes his vision of the risks induced by the new technologies (genetics, nanotechnology and robotics) and how he tries to fight them.

X.T: Why the Future Doesn't Need Us

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Here are the answers from some more or less known persons to Bill Joy's article.

X.T: Bill Joy: What I'm worried about, what I'm excited about
Bill Joy: What I'm worried about, what I'm excited about

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Bill Joy is still worried, but he describes here three solutions he is advocating by funding them: cheap computers used for education (but this requires the adequate software), new materials / nano-technologies, pandemic fight and biodefense. His conclusion on restricting information flow is quite doubtful.
Jaron tries to demolish the Cybernetic Totalists' arguments about the future technological Armageddon. This is a kind of answer to Vinge's paper.

X.T: Douglas R. Hofstadter - Singularity Summit at Stanford

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Douglas Hofstadter's critic of Ray Kurzweil books.
Roko's basilisk, when singularists become crazy.

X.T: Worlds Upon Worlds: An Illustrated Talk by Toby Lester

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The history of the Waldseemüller world map (1507), which gave America its name, and how it descends from the previous maps.

X.T: Rajesh Rao: Computing a Rosetta Stone for the Indus script
Rajesh Rao: A Rosetta Stone for a lost language

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some introductory information on the Indus script which is still undeciphered.

X.T: Jean-Baptiste Michel: The mathematics of history
Jean-Baptiste Michel: The mathematics of history

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Trying to find some numerical rules in historical data, but this is not mathematics…

X.T: The Modern Mind May Be 100,000 Years Old
X.ST: New fossil evidence shows sophisticated thought began earlier than we thought.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some 100000 years old burials, pieces of ochre and shells with a hole have been found.

X.ST: We hold this mathematics to be self evident.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Lincoln tried to applied demonstrations, as odone 2000 years before by Euclid, to politics.
A photo exhibit on Birkenau and Mauthausen, the site domain name says all that matters…
As stupid as it seems, people are fighting over who liberated the concentration camp.
Rheingold describes how the Amish are handling the new technologies, choosing to accept or not their use on a case by case basis.
This explains why and how the Mormons are creating the world genealogy database.

X.T: Putting the Fun in Functional: Applying Game Mechanics to Functional Software

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to use some attributes of games (collecting, points, feedback, exchanges, and customization) to social websites.

X.T: The Pleasure Revolution: Why Games Will Lead the Way (Jesse Schell)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is not so simple to gamify a product, it is a matter of pleasure: how to make them like more what they already like.
Cognitive ease makes us believe that the more something is repeated, the more it feels true.

X.T: Crétin de cerveau ! #1 — L'effet de Halo

ARTICLE.COMMENT: One aspect of the halo effect: the physical appearance of a person impacts how we judge some other of her/his characteristics.
Anchoring consists into giving a first piece of information to bias a subsequent judgement.

X.T: Les coûts irrécupérables — Crétin de cerveau #3

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Sunk costs are, but they should not, considered when making a new decision.

X.T: Pertes, dotation et références — Crétin de Cerveau #4

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The endowment effect.

X.T: RSA Animate - The Truth About Dishonesty

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cheating, confession, and bankers.

X.T: RSA Animate - Drive: The surprising truth about what motivates us

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: RSA Animate - The Paradox of Choice

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The negative effects of having too much choices.

X.T: Debunking myths about the "Third World" (Amazing graphics)
Debunking third-world myths with the best stats you've ever seen

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using spectacular animated graphics to show that the world is not anymore how we believe it still is. Hans Rosling also explains that the economical data he used should be free for use by all students and professors.

X.T: When Will We Discover the Extraterrestrials?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After describing how we can search for extraterrestrial life, Seth Shostak gives some information about the SETI project and why it should find something in a not so far future.

X.T: Strategies in the Search for ET

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is more or less the same presentation of the SETI project.

X.T: Spencer Wells: Building a family tree for all humanity
Spencer Wells: A family tree for humanity

ARTICLE.COMMENT: By analysing DNA of humans all around the planet, Spencer Wells tries to find out how and when the humanity conquered the world.
Applying IA to try to semantically understand the Web, first by starting with Wikipedia to bootstrap the learning.

X.T: Autonomous Vehicle Driving from Italy to China

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Experimenting partially autonomous vehicles across Europe and Asia.

X.T: How Hard Should It Be To Stop a Runaway Luxury Car?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Are the Toyota and Lexus crashes due to floor mats or to an incorrect electronic design? It is funny to see the comments on this article: this debate is very animated.

X.T: Why Japan's Fragmented Grid Can't Cope
X.ST: Bridging Japan's east-west frequency divide to stoke power flows will require real engineering hustle

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Palliating the loss of Fukushima reactors is made difficult by the fact that a half of the Japan is using 50Hz while the other half is using 60Hz.

The very common idea that more and more projects succeed by collaboration rather than by administration. Despite the fact that nothing is new here, Clay Shirky's presentation is effective to describe this.

X.T: Candy Chang: Before I die I want to…
Candy Chang: Before I die I want to ...

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A simple idea, suggesting people to write down what they want to do before their death, but the presentation presents few ideas and is overly sentimental.

X.T: CrowdInside: Automatic Construction of Indoor Floorplans

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Data mining the traces from the phone (accelerometer, magnetometer, gyroscope, and the received WiFi signals) of many persons to generate the plan of a building.

X.T: SkyLib: A Global, User-based Library for Everything

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The rational for creating a library of objects the neighbors can borrow, and some high level information about its implementation.

X.T: Organizing the World's Scientific Knowledge to make it Universally Accessible and Powerful

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another try to organize scientific data. The fact that he does not even speak about CDISC adds to my feeling of bullshit.
The story of men: australopithecus afarensis, australopithecus anamensis, homo habilis, homo ergaster, homo erectus, neanderthal, and homo sapiens.

X.T: Why the Flash Crash Really Matters
X.ST: The debate about what caused the 2010 stock market Flash Crash is missing the point.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The 2010-05-06 flash crash was not due a company selling futures or someone trying to manipulate the market, but to the fact that the system was in an unstable state.
Some ideas about the current world: the world as a city, the city as a world, frontiers…
Some examples of how a scientific theory has been accepted.
Digging in some frozen tombs to understand the history of Yakutia.

X.T: Empreinte génétique sans conscience n'est que ruine de la Justice

ARTICLE.COMMENT: DNA profiling for police investigations: DNA is not a proof, just one element of the enquiry.

X.T: Winning at Rock Paper Scissors - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The human biases when playing rock, paper, scissors.

X.T: Ma thèse en 180 secondes - Finale Bretagne

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very verbose presentation of Britain university environment, "my thesis in 180 seconds" is only a small part of this long video.

X.T: Le feu, moteur de la civilisation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A messy and uninteresting description on how humans used fire.

X.T: The window tax — an open and shut case
X.ST: ‘People respond in profound ways to tax incentives. They adjust their behaviour to avoid tax’

ARTICLE.COMMENT: People adjust their behaviour to avoid taxes.

X.T: Les ovnis : une histoire de sciences

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The evolution of how the society considers UFOs.
Stephen Wolfram quickly gives the ideas of his book "A New Kind of Science" and muses if it is the right time for him to go back to searching for the fundamental theory of physics.
The meaning of 666 in the bible.
Supersonic and hypersonic planes.
Playing with droplets of food colouring.
How people poisoned themselves…

X.T: Aliens: Are We Looking in the Wrong Place?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Trying to guess the most probable form of intelligent life.

X.T: Flywheels Keep the Grid in Tune
X.ST: Spinning masses face off against big batteries in the half-billion-dollar market for grid stability

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Flywheels and batteries are competing to be the future technology for regulating the frequency of the power grid.
An explanation of survivor bias: the mistake of only considering the surviving elements in a population.
What is the difference between a solid and a liquid?
The problems with relying on p-values to decide to publish a study.

X.T: The Secret of Floppy Paper - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The effects coming from the fact that paper is anisotropic.
How Bell Labs defined the layout of the buttons of a phone.

X.T: L'économie de la connaissance | Idriss ABERKANE

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The knowledge economy, biomimetics and the blue economy, with a lot of anecdotes/factoids.

X.T: A Nonlinear History of Time Travel
X.ST: Births, deaths, and other time travel paradoxes.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some extracts of James Gleick's new book.

X.T: Qui parle pour la science ? Idriss Aberkane ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Idriss Aberkane's resume is bullshit, but the real problem is that science popularisation is done by such persons.

X.T: La première programmeuse de l'histoire - Ada Lovelace en LEGO stop motion ft Monsieur Caron

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Is Physical Law an Alien Intelligence?
X.ST: Alien life could be so advanced it becomes indistinguishable from physics.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The idea is interesting, but there nothing much we can say about it, so the article ends up using examples corresponding to today fashionable subjects about space.

X.T: It’s Personal: Five Scientists on the Heroes Who Changed Their Lives
X.ST: Meet the inspiring people—none named Einstein—who helped these scientists find their calling.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Five scientists speak about who inspired them: a teacher, Helen Keller…
